maml:description.maml:para: Get a list of devices that can be opened by a specified token.
This cmdlet checks a device and optionally tries to determine if one or more specified tokens can open it. If no tokens are specified the current process token is used.
Specify a list of native paths to check. Can refer to object directories to search for device objects or explicit paths.
Access rights to check for in an object's access.

Possible values: None, ReadData, WriteData, AppendData, ReadEa, WriteEa, Execute, DeleteChild, ReadAttributes, WriteAttributes, GenericRead, GenericWrite, GenericExecute, GenericAll, Delete, ReadControl, WriteDac, WriteOwner, Synchronize, MaximumAllowed, AccessSystemSecurity

Check whether the device can be accessed with an EA buffer.
Check mode for device and/or namespace.

Mode for checking device object.
If CheckEaBuffer enabled specify an explicit buffer instead of a default.
When recursing specify maximum depth.
If check mode allows namespace paths specify a list of namespace paths to check for access to the device namespace instead of a default.

maml:description.maml:para: Open a NT object directory.

This cmdlet opens an existing NT object directory. It's possible to open a directory by its NT path, such as \Some\Path or it can also open a private namespace which isn't represented by an accessible NT path but instead uses a boundary descriptor.
The NT object manager path to the object to use.
Specify the access rights for a new handle when creating/opening an object.

maml:description.maml:para: Open a existing NT symbolic link object.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new NT symbolic link object.

This cmdlet creates a new NT symbolic link object. The absolute path to the object in the NT object manager name space can be specified. maml:description.maml:para: Wait on one or more NT objects to become signalled.

This cmdlet allows you to issue a wait on one or more NT objects until they become signalled. This is used for example to acquire a Mutant, decrement a Semaphore or wait for a Process to exit. The timeout value is a combination of all the allowed time parameters, e.g. if you specify 1 second and 1000 milliseconds it will actually wait 2 seconds in total. Specifying -Infinite overrides the time parameters and will wait indefinitely.
Specify a list of objects to wait on.
Specify the wait should be alertable.

Specify an infinite wait time.
